domains.name: Delivery Planning
domains.description: how work is organized, sequenced, coordinated, and validated for predictable delivery, including dependencies, risks, and alignment with the prioritized backlog.

terms.name: Phase
terms.definition: The highest-level unit of work representing a major segment of the product development lifecycle, completed when its workstreams, work packages, and tasks reach defined deliverables.
terms.description: Defines the top-level delivery lifecycle segments used to sequence work and validate completion at major checkpoints.

terms.name: Workstream
terms.definition: A coherent flow of activities within a Phase focused on a specific discipline or problem area and producing thematically related outputs.
terms.description: Organizes work by role or discipline to ensure coverage without overlap and to clarify ownership and outputs.

terms.name: Work Package
terms.definition: A structured, self-contained set of related deliverables within a Workstream, grouping multiple Tasks that collectively produce a complete output.
terms.description: Defines the delivery boundary for a meaningful chunk of output and the gate for progressing within a workstream.

terms.name: Task
terms.definition: The smallest unit of work assigned directly to an agent, producing one specific deliverable or performing one verification action.
terms.description: Defines atomic, unambiguous work units to enable deterministic execution and clear completion criteria.

terms.name: Delivery Plan
terms.definition: A structured document describing phases of work, execution order, dependencies, major activities, and delivery structure needed to complete the Product.
terms.description: Acts as the operational blueprint for coordinated execution, aligning scope, sequencing, and dependencies into a coherent plan.

terms.name: Delivery Approach
terms.definition: A high-level description of the method for delivering the Product, such as iterative delivery, feature-based delivery, incremental rollout, or hybrid approaches.
terms.description: Defines how delivery is structured and released to reduce risk and set expectations about sequencing and validation.

terms.name: Delivery Objectives
terms.definition: Specific goals the delivery process must achieve, such as predictability, reduced risk, cross-role alignment, or launch readiness.
terms.description: Defines what the delivery process must optimize for, guiding trade-offs in sequencing, coordination, and scope control.

terms.name: Delivery Assumptions
terms.definition: Documented conditions believed to be true for planning purposes, such as resource availability, technology readiness, or dependency timelines.
terms.description: Makes implicit planning expectations explicit so risks can be managed and invalid assumptions can be detected early.

terms.name: Work Breakdown Structure
terms.definition: A hierarchical decomposition of work into phases, tasks, and sub-tasks, providing a clear map of required work units.
terms.description: Defines the full decomposition of delivery work so it can be estimated, sequenced, assigned, and tracked.

terms.name: Work Package Overview
terms.definition: A summary of major Work Packages included in the delivery plan, describing their scope and purpose at a high level.
terms.description: Provides a quick structural view of what will be delivered and how work packages relate to phases and objectives.

terms.name: Timeline Plan
terms.definition: A sequenced representation of work units showing expected start dates, durations, and completion dates across the delivery lifecycle.
terms.description: Defines time-based sequencing to coordinate execution and to expose schedule feasibility and conflicts.

terms.name: Milestone Plan
terms.definition: A list of major delivery checkpoints with completion criteria and target dates used to track progress and validate outcomes.
terms.description: Defines checkpoint-based progress control so completion is validated by criteria rather than activity.

terms.name: Dependency Map
terms.definition: A structured diagram or matrix showing dependencies between tasks, roles, features, components, or technical activities.
terms.description: Defines what must be completed before other work can begin, enabling correct sequencing and risk-aware scheduling.

terms.name: Cross-Role Dependencies
terms.definition: Dependencies arising from interactions between different roles or disciplines, such as design depending on requirements or development depending on architecture readiness.
terms.description: Defines coordination constraints across roles to prevent blocking and rework due to missing upstream deliverables.

terms.name: Technical Dependencies
terms.definition: Dependencies related to technological prerequisites such as API availability, database readiness, infrastructure setup, or integration availability.
terms.description: Defines prerequisite technical work that must exist before dependent implementation can proceed safely.

terms.name: Delivery Risk
terms.definition: A potential event or condition that may negatively affect delivery timeline, scope, or quality, including impact, probability, and mitigation strategy.
terms.description: Captures delivery threats and defines mitigations so planning reflects uncertainty and avoids hidden schedule failure modes.

terms.name: Backlog–Plan Alignment Review
terms.definition: A structured evaluation ensuring the prioritized backlog is consistent with the Delivery Plan, timeline, and dependency structure.
terms.description: Validates that planned scope can be delivered within sequencing and dependency constraints and that priorities match execution reality.

terms.name: Scope and Prioritization Alignment
terms.definition: A validation that current scope and backlog priorities match strategic product scope, delivery capacity, and timeline expectations to prevent scope drift.
terms.description: Ensures that what is planned to be delivered remains aligned with strategic intent and capacity limits as planning evolves.
